results.title: The Bristol school
results.creator_credit: Nancy Hamilton, E.J. Perry and Victoria. Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
A look at the Victorian Department of Education’s work in importing 100 pressed aluminium building from Bristol, England. These buildings can be erected in 2 days and will provide accommodation of 8,000 students in an attempt to overcome overcrowding within Victorian schools.

The construction process is shown with one being assembled in the Melbourne University grounds near the Melbourne Teacher’s College.

The film print from which the digital copy was made was badly damaged and the digital version shows evidence of that.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nancy Hamilton, E.J. Perry and Victoria. Visual Education Centre

results.title: Building for learning
results.brief_description: As the Victorian population increases, the problem of providing school buildings and accomodation becomes more and more accentuated. The purpose of this film is to show the progress being made in this regard, and the problems associated with the building shortage. It also demonstrates the work being done in the various departments of the school and provides a valuable opportunity of showing to children, teachers, parents and other interested adults just what is being done in Victoria to meet the demands of a growing population for the best and the latest in the educational field. Commentary by Max Meldrum, drawings by Betty Jope.

results.title: Teachers of Tomorrow
results.brief_description: A survey of the training of Victorian Education Department teachers at the Teachers’ Training College, Melbourne, and in Victorian schools; the film is designed to encourage recruiting to the teaching profession in Victoria.

results.title: Shearing time at Billabong
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Australia’s 120 million sheep are scattered all over the continent wherever there is green grass and water. Billabong Station, in the hot dry interior, depends upon a nearby billabong to supply water to moisten the fertile soil. On the station property 40,000 sheep graze and each summer, shearing at Billabong commences. Gangs of shearers travel from far and wide to work at Billabong. The sheep are mustered by men and their dogs, sent through the drafting yards and into the shearing shed. The wool taken from the shearers is skirted, sorted, and pressed into 300-lb bales - and sent on its way to the sales. After that, Australia’s wool goes to the world.

results.title: Versifier
results.brief_description:
Gina Czarnecki’s ‘Versifier’ places the viewer alone in a room with nine naked figures.
Varying in age, race and gender, ‘Versifier’s‘ pale figures are without identity or voice, like spectres of people with a hidden past that has occurred long before our arrival. Rearprojected onto a vast screen stretched like skin across the space, these human forms suggest early nineteenth-century museum exhibits: human specimens stripped of protective layers and preserved eternally in a captive vessel.

Currently heading the Electronic Imaging Department at the University of Dundee, Gina Czarnecki works at the intersection of film, video and computer-generated imagery. In describing ‘Versifier’ she explains, ‘I have always loved the cinematic experience and came to realise that I wanted this in an installation environment. There is something about being in the dark in a public space that focuses your eyes and attention onto small details, sounds, people in the space with you or your inner thoughts and solitude.’

Once enclosed within Czarnecki’s installation, the viewer focuses on the exposed
inhabitants. With its confronting interface, Versifier challenges notions of modesty,
candour, embarrassment, fascination. Experiences that we tend to take for granted are offered up for creepily clinical re-examination. Czarnecki has used digital technology to manipulate the figures into disquieting hybrid forms: skin tones are unusually monochromatic, limbs appear disproportionate and distended. The body itself - the medium through which we all experience the world - takes on disturbing new definitions inside the specimen room that is Versifier.

Czarnecki’s mutant characters gesture forward to contemporary anxieties about the looming new frontier of genetic modification, manipulation and experimentation. But they also point backward to personal memories of vulnerability or exposure, and to communal memories of the Holocaust and genocide in which bodies were lined up and exposed in ways that were an affront to all accepted definitions of humanity. In fact, Czarnecki’s disturbing yet beautiful parade calls into question everything - past, present and future - that makes us human in the most basic, naked way.

results.title: Becoming me
results.creator_credit: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Tyson Cunningham can’t express himself, music does it for him. Although he has long given up dreams of fronting a band like his brother, music is still everything to him, and expresses his emotional life like nothing else.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Ambassador
results.brief_description:
‘The Ambassador’, is a short film featuring veteran actor, Wynn Roberts (from Picnic At Hanging Rock) as a man who writes to the Minister for the Environment to advocate for the forests and the animals that live in them.

The film is built around real events: Wynn has lived much of his 95 years in the forest. It also references climate change, ongoing logging, the staggering loss of wildlife during the recent mega fires and showcases wildlife from the southeast forests. The film won the 2020 BVSC Best Environment Film Award.

Details on Wynn Roberts can be found here - https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0731687/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1
